metadata.synopsis: Gregory Underwood (Gordon John Sinclair) is a graceless teen soccer player on a hapless team. When a girl named Dorothy (Dee Hepburn) shows up to play, things change quickly; Dorothy becomes a top player, while Gregory and the rest of the team become enamored of her. Gregory works up the courage to invite Dorothy on a date. She accepts, but Gregory finds he's been deceived into taking out another girl. Despite his confusion, Gregory eventually warms to the situation.

reviews: Forsyth has a very pleasing light touch; the movie is sweet, lulling, and often funny -- in all, perfect for young teenagers.
"Gregory's Girl" was adorably "random" before "random" was a thing.
Sweet, low-key '80s Scottish romcom has nudity, language.
The performances are lovely and the dialogue is bright -- all that's missing are more scenes between Gregory and Dorothy, since those are among the movie's best.
Bill Forsyth, formerly a maker of industrial films, made Gregory's Girl for $400,000 with a cast of non-professionals. It provides more pure entertainment than many of Hollywood's overproduced epics.
Within its modest narrative framework, Gregory's Girl strikes me as a well-nigh flawless comedy.
A charming but slight teen movie about sports, a first romance and growing up.
A funny and touching teen romance from Scottish director Bill Forsyth.
Much of the pic's peculiar fascination comes from tangential scenes, limning each character's odd obsession, be it food, girls, soccer, or just watching the traffic drive by.
As charming a provincial romance as ever there was.
Maybe only grown-ups should see this movie. You know, people who have gotten over the pains of unrequited love (hollow laugh).
The film has fresh, no-nonsense performances and a script so rooted in truth that it seems to have materialized not been written.
It floats effortlessly over its landscape, seeing all from a marvelously cockeyed perspective all its own.
What could have been a charming film about pining, becomes a confusing mess of multiple storylines that really don't amount to anything.
A revealing and credible portrait of adolescence that captures all the confusion, yearning, and terrors of adolescents trying to cope with their ambivalent desires.
It's hard to warm to a film as intentionally slight and safe as this.
